results.title: John Gilpin
results.creator_credit: Michael Warne, Joan Maude, John Halas, Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Painter and poet: an experiment in words, music and paintings”.
The fourth and final part of a series devised by Joan Maude and Michael Warre incorporating the works of writers, painters and musicians to create an experimental animated film. This part consists of one short film. ‘John Gilpin’ by William Cowper, narrated by Cecil Trouncer, drawings by Ronald Searle (9:00 mins). Photography by W. Traylor and R. Turk, music by Matyas Seiber, edited by Jack King.

results.title: John Forrest: Clydeside computer
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and London Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Pattern of People”.
John Forrest is a marine engineer leading a team of designers and engineers using a complex hybrid computer in one of the Glasgow shipyards. The film shows Forrest’s team at work on board ship, in the yards and, in an entirely different field, building a mathematical model of the blood’s chemical processes for the purposes of medical research.

results.title: John Dowie: sculptor
results.creator_credit: Film Partnership (Vic.), Alcoa Australia and Graham Bye
results.brief_description: Narrated by the sculptor, the film shows a number of works by John Dowie. The Adelaide-born sculptor uses plaster, stone, bronze and aluminium as mediums for his works. Various sculptures around Adelaide are featured; the wall reliefs in the Library of the South Australian Institute of Technology and the fountain at Victoria Square amongst them.

results.title: John Corbett: textile teacher
results.creator_credit: Nina Syme, Terry McMahon, Australia Council and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
John Corbett works at the Preston Institute, taking classes in weaving, tapestry, lace-making and other fibre work. He is a very enthusiastic teacher, although he has had no formal training he likes to bombard his students with new ideas from different people and cultures.

results.title: John Constable
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Constable’s greatness lies in his love of nature and his urge to express this love as directly as possible through a faithful transcription of its moods. Written and narrated by Sir Kenneth Clark.

results.title: John Carpenter's Vampires
results.creator_credit: Sandy King, Largo Entertainment and John Carpenter
results.brief_description: Mainly working within the parameters of the horror genre, few director’s have the popularity and cult status to warrant their name in the films title, however John Carpenter (“Halloween”, “The Thing”, “Escape from New York”, “Assault on Precinct 13”) has the body of work and the loyal followers to back it up. Based on John Steakley’s novel, “Vampires” stars James Woods as Jack Crow, a sadistic vampire slayer working for the Vatican and searching for the 600 year old originator of the blood curse. Crow and his crew of vampire hunters end up in a small town in New Mexico where they uncover a ‘nest’ of the undead. As bait they use a newly bitten prostitute (Sheryl Lee) who now has telepathic links to the master, in an effort to trap the head bloodsucker. Cast also includes Daniel Baldwin, Thomas Ian Griffith, Maximillian Schell, and Tim Guinee. Music by John Carpenter.

results.title: John Canemaker: marching to a different toon [DVD]
results.brief_description: John Canemaker is a well-regarded American animator who works in a variety of styles and has always succeeded in plumbing an array of emotions and situations in a humorous and engaging manner. Canemaker is also an esteemed animation historian and biographer. His fluid style, hand drawn and quite low-tech, is unpredictable and highly entertaining, cleverly evolving from one moment to the next. “Confessions of a star dreamer”: An actress and vamp discusses her feelings toward procreating, her craft and the industry. “Bridgehampton”: With music by Fred Hersch, this piece elegantly portrays a suburban changing of the seasons. “Confessions of a stand-up”: Wonderful piece satirising the pitfalls and pratfalls of being a comedian, as told by Dennis Blair. “Bottom’s dream”: Canemaker reworks the notions underpinning Shakespearean comical character, Bottom. “The Wizard’s son”: The young son of a wizard imagines the possibilities and adventures that await him, wreaking havoc in the meantime. “Behind the scenes”: An absurd piece on the interaction between line, form and shape. Bonus material includes excerpts from: “The Creative spirit” with a commentary about creative thought and processes; “Laughter is good medicine”; “Break the silence: kids against child abuse”; “What do children think when they think of the bomb”; “Science experiences”; and three thirty second advertisements for AIDS benefits.

results.title: John Brown, Rose and the Midnight Cat (K)
results.brief_description: Illustrations by Ron Brooks from the book of the same name by Australian writer Jenny Wagner are used to tell the story of Rose, an old widow, and John Brown, her trusty sheep dog, who live together comfortably until a midnight cat strays into their garden and challenges John Brown for Rose’s affections. Adaptation by Ernest Troost. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: John Barrymore
results.creator_credit: David L. Wolper and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biography”.
Portrays events in the life of film and theatre idol John Barrymore, using photographs and film footage. An excellent, insightful and refreshingly unsentimental biography. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
